job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Many of the people that work within the business school are delightful and driven by passion and ethics. I've met some wonderful people there that were my colleagues, employees and more.
cons:
If you're thinking of working within the business school... RUN. The school has gone through a lot of ups and downs over the past 5 years and is worse than ever as far as turnover (both voluntary and involuntary), lack of opportunities, poor senior management and low morale. Unfortunately, it seems the "good people" were always the target of so many misguided and failed attempts to try to cut costs or fuel the ego of a senior executive. 

Since the jobs are not well-paid, the school used to emphasize the benefits of work-life balance as a selling point. However, the majority of people I know there have less work-life balance than other industries that pay 2x as much. Most people find themselves working 10+ hour days and on weekends for jobs that are largely 40-80k max without any type of bonuses or ways to make extra income based on success and efforts. You're lucky if you get a pat on the back.

review_title: Comfortable and low-key, but not challenging
pros: Low-stress, great benefits, great pay. The office I worked in had mostly great coworkers. It felt like a group of friends, people look out for each other and help one another out. Staff in general is incredibly friendly and warm. It's easy to predict busy times since it's a university. Absolutely beautiful location! It's a pretty good place to work overall. You're treated very well and mistakes are forgiven and easily overlooked.
cons:
Not sure if this throughout the whole university or just in my department, but I noticed sexism, cronyism, and poor leadership. Some staff members (including some leaders) did treat women differently than men. I knew several staff members who either did hardly any work or who were in leadership positions but were clearly not qualified do the job well. And some leaders hardly interacted with their staff; they seemed invisible. 

Also, employees seem to be very complacent with their work and motivation. People work slow and they like it that way. It's rare to find an employee there who tries to push their department or new ideas forward. And if they do, they're usually met with resistance and management chooses to do things the old way. if you're looking for a challenge and a work environment open to new ideas this is not the place for you.

pros: I have worked in the MBA program for two years now.  Overall, the other instructors are intelligent, high quality individuals.  The department chairs are also good people.
cons:
For the most part, the students in the MBA program are terrible.  Pepperdine has several MBA/MS programs that are all geared towards students who are extremely young with little to no work experience.  Because of this, the university cannot attract the high caliber students that other top end schools can attract.  The students are immature, disrespectful, and quite needy.  A typical class involves several students holding side conversations while an instructor attempts to give a lecture.  These same students then complain to the administration when they receive poor grades.  The administration is there to pacify the students and to keep the money rolling in, so it overturns poor grades to keep students happy.  How does this build a quality program when poor performance is rewarded?  

Also, students continually ask why they cannot find jobs post graduation.  Well, this is likely because the MBA that you just earned is not worth the paper that it is printed on because students do not have any meaningful work experience to justify employment.  Don't believe me, look at the recruiting stats.

pros: I got a relevant job when I needed one and facilities are nice.
cons: The Graduate School of Education and Psychology is a nightmare, and got even worse with the new dean Helen Easterling Williams. Staff morale is at an all time low, good workers were let go in order for Helen to achieve some hare brained pet projects. The faculty are so miserable they refuse to come to the main GSEP West LA campus unless they have to, which is actually a plus because so many of th are so snooty and rude to the staff.  Everyone is trying to leave, myself included.  People who have left have all told HR of the problems Helen has caused, but no one will do anything because she's Pepperdine's first black dean. Do not work here!

job_title: Student Services Coordinator  in Malibu, CA
pros: The management cares for employees, students, staff, and faculty.  You feel like you are part of a family, and people genuinely care to make relationships with you to make a more positive environment.  After working here I truly feel that students are extremely lucky to be able to go to this school.  It's a fantastic place to study and to work.  Plus the view of the ocean is stunning!  Pepperdine taught me a lot about how a private university works, and what public universities should aim to be like.
cons: Not a whole lot of food options close by the campus.  Dining hall closes up early, so if you take a late lunch, you're forced to find something off campus.  There are some great restaurants nearby, but they can get old and expensive after some time.  Fortunately, Santa Monica is a mere 10 minute drive away, so there's tons of options there.

pros: The school offers a great benefits package to faculty and staff of Pepperdine.  Most importantly, the discount on tuition available to faculty and staff is amazing.  Depending on how many yrs youve given to the university determines your tuition discount.  They also offer great medical and dental benefits.  Pepperdine also provides a safe environment to work in, as the school is a closed campus.  Also, unless you royally screw up, once you're in the Pepperdine family, you are in, and don't have to worry about job security, because even if they get rid of your job they'll find somewhere to put you.
cons:
Communication amongst the university's employees could be better.  It seems as if information that is relevant to some departments is not always shared with those respective departments.  
It would be nice if the university was able to arrange for suitable living arrangements for staff members, as living in malibu is very expensive.  Most commute from far away distances.

review_title: Pepperdine University is a community of people working together to shape the hearts, souls, and minds of its students.
pros: Authentic People, Place of Faith, Passionately Inspired, Purposeful Leadership, Values-Centered Work...the work of employees at Pepperdine is about influencing the world for good by equipping young people with the knowledge, skills, and experiences they need, with a foundation of values and purpose.  That is the kind of "product" I can get behind.
cons: Many perceive Pepperdine to be a very affluent school and expect budgets and salaries to be sky high.  However, Pepperdine, like many private colleges, is a non-profit organization, 75 years young, and committed to fiscal stewardship and responsibility.  We have been blessed in many ways, but job seekers should have a realistic understanding of the financial parameters and limitations the institution faces.

pros: Pepperdine is a generally wonderful place. The people are nice, the faculty are brilliant, coworkers are kind and supportive to each other, and the benefits are good. I feel truly lucky to be able to work here!
cons: The staff and students tend to rely on the beauty of our location. Who cares if you don't make what you deserve when you work AT THE BEACH? I have heard so many people say, "It sucks, but I mean look at this view!" I've even had friends and family tell me that whenever I've expressed discontent. Yes, the campus is beautiful, but that shouldn't mean that fair employee compensation is overlooked. I'm pretty sure most people who are not in high senior positions don't make even close to a living wage...I certainly don't!

review_title: You couldn't ask for a place with better spirit
pros: The core vision of the University "Freely you have been given, freely give" truly applies from the top to the bottom at the University.  The staff, the faculty, the students all CARE.  Seriously.  These are people who have great heart and want to make a lasting positive impact on people who can then take what they've learned to make a lasting positive impact in the world.

pros: The people who work there really believe in the mission, care about the students, and support each other. You can go to fitness classes or to the beach on your lunch break! The work itself is rewarding as well.
cons: You have to jump through a lot of hoops to get anything done. Lots of bureaucracy. Micromanagement is common, at least in my experience. It is also a small university, so you often need to promote to other departments to move up, which can be difficult.

review_title: Friendly, professional and respectful work environment

review_title: PTSD after three years at GSBM
pros: Discount on tuition, small handful of likable coworkers, West LA campus was a short commute for me.  Work hours were fairly stable. I was rarely asked or needed to stay late. Occasionally, after a catered a lunch for faculty, staff members were permitted to pick over the leftovers if we brought our own paper plates -- that was always a treat.
cons:
It's been a while, so I can't say if the same holds true, but

The school abides by a mantra of "values-centered leadership," but during my three-year stint as a mid-level marketing team member, I witnessed nothing that resembled values or leadership. The executive management led with an archaic leadership style, and it was a powerless feeling to watch a rapid fire of poor decisions lead to a series of lay-offs and unexpected resignations. The longer I stayed, the worse it got.  

There is a huge disconnect between the West LA campus and the Malibu hub. I once tried to call a human resources colleague to complain and eventually gave up after three days of being unable to reach someone. 

The vibe of the office teetered between Christian cult and Caucasian clubhouse. It was uptight and boring, so if you are a creative type or have a personality, you might have a hard time being yourself at work. Also, get ready for long and plentiful pointless meetings where people take credit for the work of others and nothing really gets accomplished. 

I couldn't make ends meet on the crappy salary they paid me, and I suffered a terrible financial hardship during my time there. I think they saw an opportunity in light of the poor economic climate and took that opportunity to pay me less than the average college graduates a decade my junior despite my 12 years of professional experience. 
 
I reported to several supervisors, each operating under their own brand of oblivion, the worst being my direct supervisor whose mental instability went largely unaddressed and eventually led to my unceremonious departure and still leaves me with a terrible taste in my mouth.

It was an upsetting experience--one that often bordered on abusive--but if anything good has come of it, it's that I am that so grateful for the normalcy of the opportunities that have followed, and I don't put up with this kind of crap anymore.
